    • The gas clean-up stage removes sulphur from the combustion gas, and the gas combustion and expansion stage generates power by combusting the combustion gas with oxygen.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention provides a method for preparing a solid device for use as an oxide superconducting material, which has a highly reliable surface utilizing device.
    * The method involves the provision of a blocking film (passivation film) which is uniformly coated over the spaces or micro-holes in the surface portion of the superconducting material to prevent the removal of oxygen from that portion.
    * The blocking film is formed on the surface of the superconducting material at a thickness of 10 Å to 2μm using a photo CVD method, and is converted by heat treatment to a highly dense insulating material to provide a more complete blocking layer.
* The superconducting material is an oxide superconducting material, which is formed into tablets or a thin film, and is used in a Josephson element structure or as a passivation film.
    * The oxide superconducting material is formed using a method such as the photo CVD method, and is characterized by a large number of micro-holes or spaces on its surface, which are filled with a solid material to provide a high degree of reliability.
    * The blocking film is formed using a method such as the photo CVD method, and is converted by heat treatment to a highly dense insulating material to provide a more complete blocking layer.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination.
  • The apparatus includes a base structure, a clamping arrangement, and a planar surface for interacting with a cutting knife.
    • The clamping arrangement is used to grasp the foam sheet sample without damaging it, and the planar surface is used to make parallel cuts in the sample.
• The apparatus is designed to prepare samples with parallel cut edges that are suitable for microscopic examination.
  • The apparatus can be used to prepare samples with different thicknesses by advancing the hand nut to different stop positions.
    • The samples can be used to examine the structure of the individual cells within the foam sheet material.
</summary>

<summary>
  * The invention relates to seismometers, particularly those designed to operate on the ocean floor, and provides a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination with respect to the vertical assumed by such a unit during its operation.
    * The apparatus includes a seismic motion detector suspended at the end of a shaft protruding from a ball rotating in an annular seat to form a free-moving pendulum.
      * The detector is connected to a plunger that can be extended to lock the ball, shaft, and detector in their assumed orientation.
      * The plunger is restrained from contacting the ball by a pin that is removed by a solenoid when the plunger is extended.
      * The solenoid is activated by an electric current, which is controlled by a power source and a control system.
      * The invention also provides a method for automatically leveling seismic motion detectors used in a seismometer.
      * The method includes suspending the detector at the end of a shaft and allowing it to hang freely, which aligns its operating axis with the vertical.
      * The invention is useful for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer on the ocean floor and for leveling seismic motion detectors.
      * The invention is particularly useful for ocean bottom seismometers, which are used in oil and natural gas exploration.
      * The invention provides a simple and inexpensive method for determining the angle of inclination and leveling seismic motion detectors.

<summary>
• The present invention provides a humidity sensing element that is energized by low voltage microscopic currents from solid state electronic instrumentation, does not depend on mechanical movements, and is physically sturdy and requires no special physical protection.
  • The element consists of a first electron conductive electrode, a porous coating of dielectric, minute particles of electron conductive material deposited in the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric, a second electron conductive electrode pervious to moisture vapor, and an ion-forming material in the dielectric.
    • The impedance between the electrodes varies generally linearly with relation to the relative humidity of the surrounding gaseous atmosphere in a suitable range of interest when excited by a suitable alternating current voltage.
• The preferred embodiment of the invention includes an anodized layer of aluminum oxide or alumina (Al2O3) with a thickness of about 0.02 to 0.08 millimeters, minute particles of nickel deposited in the interstices of the porosity of the anodized layer, and a second electrode formed by vacuum deposition of nickel onto the sealed anodized layer.
  • The sensor is suitable for excitation by a ten Hertz sine wave alternating current electrical voltage impressed across its electrodes by a solid state electronic measurement circuit.
    • The sensor is self-contained and forms its own protection for the humidity-sensitive portion in its bore, while the surrounding atmosphere may circulate freely through the bore for free exchange of atmospheric molecules with the dielectric layer.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure.
    * The force transmission structure includes a drive plate and a shaft.
        * The drive plate has a mounting hole with at least three sections interconnected at a common area.
        * The shaft has a toothed portion with at least three teeth fittingly received in the sections of the mounting hole.
* The motor assembly also includes a gear train connecting the motor to the drive plate.
    * The gear train includes a worm driven by the motor, a worm gear meshed with the worm, and a damper attached to and rotatable with the worm gear.
        * The drive plate is driven by the worm gear through the damper.
* The invention provides a stable and quiet operation of the motor assembly.
    * The Y-shaped toothed portion of the shaft extends through the inner ring of the worm gear to be fitted in the Y-shaped mounting hole of the drive plate.
    * The free end of the toothed portion of the shaft extends beyond the coupling of the drive plate.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver.
    • The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem, and a baseband subsystem.
    • The radio frequency subsystem includes a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator.
    • The baseband subsystem includes a free running counter that generates the mobile time reference.
    • The free running counter uses the high frequency oscillator to generate the mobile time reference when it is available, and the low frequency oscillator to maintain the mobile time reference when it is not available.
    • The mobile time reference is used to detect, identify, and monitor multipath signals in a WCDMA system.
    • The system also includes a multipath monitor and a multipath radio signal recovery circuit that use the mobile time reference to recover multipath signals.
    • The system provides a fast wakeup mechanism that recovers multiple hypotheses in parallel to arrive quickly at a time base that can initiate subsequent demodulation of the spread spectrum signal.
</summary>

<summary>
  * Background of the Invention
    * Protective helmets with hard outer shells are known, but they often have a resilient liner assembly to absorb shock, which can be adjusted to fit different head sizes.
  * Previous methods of making custom-fitted helmets have limitations, such as requiring direct handling of foaming agents or complex manufacturing processes.
  * The present invention aims to provide a helmet liner that can be fitted to an individual's head rapidly and simply, and can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size.
  * The liner consists of multiple layers of elastic thermoplastic sheets with hollow spherical protuberances, which are arranged in a specific way to provide a custom fit.
  * The layers are vacuum-formed over a hemispherical dome and are trimmed to the required shape.
  * The liner is secured to the helmet shell using fasteners, and the edges are glued or otherwise secured together.
  * The liner is heated to a plastic state, placed on the wearer's head, and pressed firmly to deform the sheets to the desired extent.
  * The liner can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size by reheating and re-deforming the sheets.
  * The invention provides a simple and inexpensive manufacturing process, and the liner does not require drawstrings or trimming after fitting.
</summary>

<summary>
• Multiorifice structure for atomizing fluid
  • Consists of alternating layers of rods and cylindrical members
  • Rods are angularly disposed with respect to the axis of the structure
  • Cylindrical members separate the rods and provide a path for the fluid to flow
  • The structure is designed to produce a spray cone with a specific angle
  • The structure is made by fusing or sintering the rods and cylindrical members together

• Method of making the multiorifice structure
  • Fusing or sintering the rods and cylindrical members together
  • The rods and cylindrical members are coated with a thin layer of material having a lower melting temperature
  • The structure is sliced or cut to produce a plurality of thin multiorifice structures
  • The sliced surfaces are ground or polished to produce a required surface finish or uniformity of thickness
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device, particularly an insulated gate (MOS) field effect semiconductor device having a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
    * The method includes forming a gate insulating film and a gate electrode on a substrate, and then forming a low concentration n-type region by injecting a low concentration n-type impurity under a low acceleration voltage while using the gate electrode as a mask.
    * The method also includes forming a high concentration n-type region by injecting a high concentration n-type impurity under a high acceleration voltage while using the gate electrode and a portion of the gate insulating film as a mask.
    * The method further includes forming a conductive layer on the substrate, and then anisotropically etching the conductive layer to form a portion on the gate sidewall, and then removing the portion of the gate insulating film and the gate electrode.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to Internet telephony and provides an improved end-user interface for IP telephone communication.
    * The invention fulfills the need for a low-cost, low-power, and efficient IP telephone system.
    * The invention provides a radio telephone that can be connected to a PC and used as a significantly improved IP telephone.
    * The radio telephone includes an internal speech coder and allows for low-power consumption and low-cost implementation.
    * The invention provides a convenient and comfortable handset for the near-end user and reduces the echo problem associated with conventional IP telephones.
    * The invention can be used in various network links, including a PSTN, a wireless radio system, or a public or private data network.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to devices for producing electrical power from surface waves on a water body.
    * The device uses one or more gas-filled containers submerged to a depth slightly below the anticipated wave and swell troughs.
        * The containers have a fixed depth rigid end or surface held at a relatively fixed depth relative to the water body mean water level or wave troughs by a flexible anchoring means, with horizontal depth stabilization discs or drag plates, or by a rigid sea bed attached spar or mast, or the bottom itself.
        * The containers are connected by and sealed to a flexible, gas-tight, reinforced, elastomer or flexible metal bellows, or a diaphragm or accordion-pleated skirt, also suitably reinforced against collapse from container internal vacuum or external hydrostatic pressure.
        * The containers are designed to expand and contract in response to overhead wave-induced hydrostatic pressure variations, producing a linear motion that is connected to and transferred to a hydraulic or pneumatic pumping means or mechanical or electrical drive means.
        * The pressurized fluid flow from the hydraulic or pneumatic pumping can drive a motor or turbine with an electric generator, or mechanical means can direct drive a generator via rack and pinion gearing, oscillating helical drive, or other oscillating linear one-way rotational motion means.
</summary>

<summary>
• Invention Overview
  • The invention pertains to the field of scraped surface heat exchangers
  • It relates to the mounting of blades for a scraped surface heat exchanger onto a central drive shaft
  • The invention aims to facilitate the mounting of blades while using a pin type connection

• Problem Statement
  • Current methods of mounting blades are cumbersome and require manual holding or stringing
  • Blades may swing outwardly and fall freely during installation, requiring repositioning
  • The invention aims to address these issues

• Solution
  • The invention provides a blade with L-shaped locking tracks on both sides
  • The tracks have entry tracks and intermediate tracks that interact with the pins
  • The blade is installed by sliding it onto the pins, then rotating it to the installation angle
  • The tracks prevent the blade from falling off the pins during installation

• Advantages
  • The invention provides a secure and efficient method of mounting blades
  • The tracks on both sides of the blade ensure structural rigidity and reduce wear
  • The invention is suitable for both horizontal and vertical heat exchangers
  • The invention ensures correct orientation of the scraper edge during installation

• Installation Process
  • The blade is placed at an angle relative to the pins
  • The inner fingers of the pins slide into the entry tracks of the blade
  • The blade is then slid onto the pins, with the inner fingers aligned with the mounting holes
  • The blade is rotated to the installation angle, with the outer fingers aligned with the intermediate tracks

• Conclusion
  • The invention provides a novel and improved method of mounting blades for scraped surface heat exchangers
  • The invention addresses the problems of current methods and provides a secure and efficient solution
  • The invention is suitable for a wide range of applications and industries
  • The invention is a significant improvement over current methods and technologies

</summary>

<summary>

* The invention relates to a process and apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine.
    * The cigarette magazine has a storage part and four shaft groups arranged beneath it.
    * The cigarettes are monitored by a camera and an image-processing device.
    * The camera scans an image of the cigarette magazine and the image-processing device evaluates the image.
    * If a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected, an error signal is produced.
    * The error signal actuates an ejecting unit, which ejects the defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette.
    * The ejecting unit has a housing, a carriage, and an ejector.
    * The ejecting unit is actuated by a connecting element and a connecting rod.
    * The ejecting unit can be actuated manually or automatically.
    * The invention provides a reliable and efficient way to detect and eliminate defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine.

</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to a device for interconnecting high voltage cables with apparatus and/or other high voltage cables, comprising a cable termination and a rigid insulator.
    * The device provides a simplified connection system for high voltage cables with ratings up to 400 KV and above.
        * The interface between the cable end and any accessory, between two cable ends, or between two apparatus is generally applicable, resulting in a number of advantages, such as factory pretesting, reduction of installation time and cost, reduction of tools, and simplified field testing.
        * The stress cone design and dimensions are the same for all applications, with the only variation being the diameter of the cable or apparatus entrance.
* The invention provides a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections, with a number of advantages, including:
    * Factory pretesting
    * Reduction of installation time and cost
    * Reduction of tools
    * Simplified field testing
    * No gas or oil is included in the interface components, eliminating the risk of leaks or explosions
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a fixing mechanism for a tool used in machining, particularly in cutting, punching, molding, and forming work, such as machining metal sheets in sheet machining centers.
    * The fixing mechanism is designed to improve the prior art by providing a simple and secure way to fix the tool to the machine tool, allowing for easy exchange of tools and reducing the risk of damage to the tool or machine.
        * The mechanism uses a curved surface, such as a spherical surface, to connect the tool frame to the tool holder, allowing for a secure and precise fit.
        * The mechanism also includes a clamp to apply pressure to the tool frame and tool holder, ensuring a secure connection and allowing for the transmission of forces in the mounting direction.
        * The mechanism is designed to be adjustable, allowing for easy release and reattachment of the tool to the machine tool.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention provides methods and apparatus for producing low EMI energy at levels necessary to drive varying sizes of digital displays.
    * The invention uses a switching regulator circuit that operates at high speeds while producing low EMI output.
</summary>

<summary>
* Vehicle battery rebalancing is performed to correct cell voltage imbalance conditions. This is done by measuring the voltage of each cell, identifying the cell with the minimum voltage, and bleeding down the other cells until they have a measured voltage approximately equal to the minimum.
    * The rate at which charge is acquired by the cells may be different among at least some of the cells for at least a determined portion of the period of time.
    * The battery pack charge time is dependent on the cell requiring the greatest ΔIhrs, the cell requiring the least ΔIhrs, the method of balancing the cells to the same voltage, and the portion of the charge cycle selected to balance the cells.
* A method of determining the desired voltage would include calculating the required cell voltage as above using the minimum Amp-hr cell, summing the string energy from (9), and comparing the calculated energy with the required trip energy.
    * If the energy is too great, then an incrementally smaller assumed voltage could be used and the summation process repeated until the desired energy level is reached.
    * A similar process could also be used starting from the cell with the maximum Amp-hr capacity.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter that converts a low-frequency AC input voltage to a constant DC output voltage, reducing eye fatigue and preventing myopia.
  • The converter uses a Flyback topology and a control circuit to regulate the output voltage and dim the lamp.
    • The control circuit can be implemented using various IC controllers, such as iW2202, iW2210, or iW1688.
• The invention also includes an input protection circuit, an EMI filter, a rectifier, a filter, and an output filter to ensure safe and efficient operation.
  • The input protection circuit includes overcurrent and overvoltage protection, while the EMI filter reduces electromagnetic radiation.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a system for controlling the illumination levels in a space, including both daylight and artificial lighting, and for reducing sun glare.
    • The system includes a central processor, a dimming panel, and one or more photosensors.
        • The central processor is a Lutron GRAFIK 6000 central lighting processor.
        • The dimming panel is a Lutron type GP12-1203ML-15.
        • The photosensors are microWATT photosensors available from Lutron model No. MW-PS-WH.
    • The system also includes a photosensor interface, a wall station, and a window treatment controller.
        • The photosensor interface is coupled to the central processor and the photosensors.
        • The wall station is provided for manual control of the various lighting loads.
        • The window treatment controller is a Lutron GRAFIK 6000 Sivoia controller model No. SO-SVCI-WH-EO1.
    • The system can be programmed and monitored using a personal computer.
        • The system can be used to create and recall custom preset scenes.
        • The system can be used to control the lighting levels in a space to achieve a desired illumination profile.
    • The system can also be used to reduce sun glare by controlling the window treatments.
        • The system can be used to adjust the window treatments to minimize glare.
        • The system can be used to adjust the window treatments to maximize daylight.
</summary>

<summary>

* Aviation security has made significant progress since September 2001, but challenges remain.
	* * TSA has implemented various security measures, including passenger screening, baggage screening, and air cargo security.
	* * However, vulnerabilities still exist, such as air cargo security, general aviation security, and airport perimeter security.
* TSA faces challenges in sustaining aviation security over the long term.
	* * * The agency needs to continue to build a results-oriented culture and improve its performance management system.
	* * * TSA must also address the need for more effective risk assessments and plans to balance security and customer service.
* Funding is a major concern for TSA.
	* * * The agency has requested $4.2 billion for aviation security in fiscal year 2004, but the cost of integrating explosives detection equipment into baggage-handling systems is estimated to be $3 billion.
	* * * TSA has proposed reprogramming funds to address these costs, but this has raised concerns about accountability.
* TSA's workforce is also a challenge.
	* * * The agency has hired over 60,000 people, but it needs to "right-size" its workforce as efficiency improves with new security-enhancing technologies and procedures.
	* * * TSA has proposed reducing its screener workforce by 6,000 by September 30, 2003, and an additional 3,000 in fiscal year 2004.
* TSA's relationship with airports and local law enforcement agencies is also a challenge.
	* * * The agency needs to establish clear roles and responsibilities and improve communication with these entities.
	* * * TSA has deployed 158 federal security directors to airports, but airport representatives have expressed concerns about the relationships between federal security directors and airport operators.
* The Department of Homeland Security's merger and transformation is also a challenge.
	* * * TSA must continue to build a results-oriented culture and improve its performance management system as part of the merger.
	* * * The agency must also establish a coherent mission and integrated strategic goals to guide the transformation.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect who must register and what they must report.
	* The LDA definition covers contacts with federal officials, while the IRC definitions cover contacts with federal, state, and local officials.
	* The LDA definition also covers non-legislative matters, while the IRC definitions do not.
	* The differences in definitions can result in organizations not registering under LDA or reporting information that is not comparable.
	* The LDA requires organizations to report their lobbying expenses and activities, while the IRC definitions do not.
	* The LDA also requires organizations to report their lobbying expenses and activities in a specific format, while the IRC definitions do not.
	* The differences in definitions can also result in organizations reporting different information, which can make it difficult to compare the data.

</summary>

<summary>

  • Companies have successfully implemented strategic sourcing for services, which can be a key area for federal agencies to focus on.

  • However, more needs to be done to overcome the challenges and achieve significant savings.
  • The government can learn from companies that have successfully implemented strategic sourcing, including the importance of leadership, shared data, and a focus on strategic categories.
  • The government should prioritize strategic sourcing efforts, particularly in high-spend categories like services, to achieve significant savings and improve procurement efficiency.
</summary>

<summary>
• The current funding system for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is based on excise taxes, which are not directly linked to the costs of services provided by the FAA. This can lead to revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency concerns.
	• The current system does not provide a direct link between the costs of services and the revenues generated, which can lead to inefficiencies and inequities.
	• The current system also does not provide incentives for users to use the system efficiently, as the costs of services are not directly tied to the use of the system.

• Alternative funding options, such as weight/distance charges, en-route charges, and flight segment charges, have been proposed to address these concerns.
	• These alternative funding options aim to create a more direct link between the costs of services and the revenues generated, which can help to address revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency concerns.
	• These alternative funding options also aim to provide incentives for users to use the system efficiently, as the costs of services are directly tied to the use of the system.
</summary>

<summary>

* DOD's current effort to identify individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances during tests conducted outside of Project 112 lacks clear and consistent objectives, scope of work, and information needs.
	* The objectives of the effort are inconsistent, and the scope of work has expanded to include exposures from immunizations, transportation, storage, and occupational accidents.
	* The information needs of the effort are unclear, and the contractor has been collecting information that is not necessary for the task.
* The effort lacks adequate oversight, with no clear lines of accountability and no regular evaluation of the contractor's work.
	* The contractor has not been actively searched for additional individuals, and the effort has not been focused on the most critical areas.
	* The contractor has not been held accountable for the accuracy and completeness of the information it has collected.
* The effort has not been transparent, with no regular updates provided to Congress, veterans, and the public.
	* The effort has not been coordinated with other organizations that have previously identified exposed individuals, such as the Institute of Medicine.
* The effort has not been effective in notifying individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances, with only 48% of identified individuals receiving notification letters.
	* The effort has been hindered by a lack of resources, including personnel and funding, and by the difficulty of obtaining accurate and complete information from the contractor.

<summary>

* The US government has been working to combat firearms trafficking to Mexico, with a focus on tracing the origin of firearms seized in Mexico.
	* The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) has been tracing firearms seized in Mexico and has found that most of them originated in the US.
* The ATF has implemented several measures to combat firearms trafficking, including the use of eTrace, a system that allows law enforcement agencies to trace the origin of firearms.
	* The ATF has also provided training to Mexican law enforcement agencies on the use of eTrace and has worked with them to identify and prosecute firearms traffickers.
* The US government has also worked with Mexico to improve border security and to prevent the smuggling of firearms into Mexico.
	* The US and Mexico have also worked together to disrupt the operations of criminal organizations involved in firearms trafficking.
* The ATF has also worked with other US agencies, such as the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) and the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), to combat firearms trafficking.
	* The ATF has also worked with international partners, such as the Mexican government, to combat firearms trafficking.

</summary>

<summary>

* NCHIP (National Criminal History Improvement Program) is a federal program that aims to improve the quality, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records.
	* * The program provides grants to states to automate and improve their criminal history records systems.
	* * The program also encourages states to participate in national criminal history records systems, such as NICS (National Instant Criminal Background Check System) and NCIC (National Crime Information Center).
	* * The program has provided over $438 million in federal grants since its inception in 1995.
* NCHIP has made significant progress in automating and improving criminal history records, but there is still much work to be done.
	* * Many states still have incomplete or inaccurate records, and some states have not contributed to national criminal history records systems.
	* * The program faces challenges in addressing the demand for background checks, which is growing due to increased requirements for employment and homeland security.
	* * The program also faces challenges in addressing the need for long-term funding to support the development and maintenance of criminal history records systems.
* The program has developed a tool called RQI (Criminal History Records Quality Index) to measure the quality and completeness of criminal history records.
	* * RQI will be used to evaluate the performance of states and identify areas for improvement.
	* * The program plans to use RQI to target future assistance to states and local participants in federal funding programs.
* The program has received support from the Department of Justice and has been praised for its efforts to improve criminal history records.
	* * The program has been recognized for its efforts to improve the accuracy and completeness of criminal history records.
	* * The program has also been recognized for its efforts to increase the accessibility of criminal history records to law enforcement agencies and other authorized users.

</summary>

<summary>
• EPA's oversight of incinerators at Superfund sites is inadequate, with no formal mechanism to ensure that lessons learned from each site are shared with other sites.
	• The agency has not followed its own policy of having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators, and has not developed a single document specifying site-specific operating requirements and procedures for these incinerators.
	• The agency has not implemented a systematic process to share information on safe operation from one site to another, and has not documented lessons learned from each site.
	• The agency has not followed through on other opportunities to improve its oversight of incinerators, such as having RCRA inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and developing a single document specifying site-specific operating requirements and procedures.
</summary>

<summary>

• **Material Weakness in Internal Control**
  • The SEC did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007, due to a material weakness in its financial reporting process.
  • The material weakness was caused by a combination of control deficiencies in period-end financial reporting, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures.

• **Control Deficiencies**
  • The SEC identified three significant deficiencies in internal control, which although not material weaknesses, represent significant deficiencies in the design or operation of internal control.
  • The deficiencies concern property and equipment, accounting for budgetary resources, and information security.

• **Financial Reporting Process**
  • The SEC's financial reporting process is manual and labor-intensive, with extensive use of spreadsheets and manual journal entries.
  • The process is prone to errors and does not provide reasonable assurance that financial statements are accurate and complete.

• **Disgorgements and Penalties Accounts Receivable**
  • The SEC's process for calculating accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties is prone to errors and does not provide reasonable assurance that the amounts are accurate.
  • The SEC made errors in calculating the amounts, which were not material but could have been material if not corrected.

• **Transaction Fee Revenue**
  • The SEC's process for accounting for transaction fee revenue is not integrated with its general ledger system, which increases the risk of errors.
  • The SEC made an error in estimating the amount of transaction fee revenue, which was corrected through an adjusting journal entry.

• **Financial Statement Disclosures**
  • The SEC's financial statement disclosures contained errors, including misstated amounts, improper breakout of line items, and incorrect classification of amounts.
  • The errors were caused by a lack of a documented timeline and process for completing the financial statements and disclosures.

• **Information Security**
  • The SEC has not consistently implemented key elements of its information security program, which increases the risk of unauthorized access to sensitive data and systems.
  • The SEC has identified weaknesses in its information security controls, including authorization, boundary protection, configuration management, and audit and monitoring.

</summary>

<summary>

* The Postal Service's diversity program was evaluated by Aguirre International, which found that a "glass ceiling" existed at positions beginning at EAS 17, preventing women and minorities from advancing to higher levels.
	* The study used multiple methodologies, including data analysis and site visits, to assess the Service's diversity program.
	* The study found that women and minorities were underrepresented in EAS 17 and above positions, and that a perceived "old boy network" prevented them from advancing.
* The Postal Service has implemented 23 initiatives to improve its diversity program, including revising the Diversity Business Plan and establishing a Diversity Oversight Group.
	* The initiatives aim to improve diversity in hiring, promotion, and supplier diversity, and to increase the representation of women and minorities in the workforce.
* The Service has not yet established targets and measures to track its progress in meeting its diversity goals and objectives.
	* The Service is working to develop specific targets and measures, but has not yet captured reliable EEO data on promotion applicants' progress through the promotion process.
* The Service is recommended to ensure that EEO group data is captured in the AFTS and used to improve the diversity program, including identifying barriers to promotions to high-level EAS positions.
	* The Service has concurred with the recommendation and will reemphasize the need to enter data into the Promotion Report System.

</summary>

<summary>
• Military Working Dogs (MWDs) are bred, procured, or acquired to support military operations, including explosive and illegal narcotic detection, patrol, and tracking. They are removed from service when they can no longer perform their duties due to medical or behavior problems, or when they are no longer needed by the military.
  •   MWDs are adopted after their military service through a process that prioritizes former handlers, followed by others capable of caring for the dogs, and then law enforcement agencies.
  •   The US War Dogs Association provides assistance with privately provided veterinary care, including prescription drugs, specialty care, and financial assistance for emergency care and euthanasia.
  •   Some MWDs may require costly medical treatment, and the costs can vary depending on the condition, course of treatment, and location.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Comanche helicopter program was established in 1983 to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet.
	* The program aimed to design a low-cost, lightweight, advanced technology helicopter capable of performing armed reconnaissance and attack missions.
	* The program was expected to develop advanced technologies, including composite materials, advanced avionics, and sophisticated software and hardware.
	* The Army must meet ambitious maintainability goals to achieve lower operating and support costs and wartime operational availability.
	* The program was restructured in 1994 due to budget constraints, reducing funding from $4.2 billion to $2.2 billion for fiscal years 1996-2001.

* The program has experienced significant cost increases, with the estimated total program acquisition cost increasing from $61 billion in 1985 to $44 billion in 1995.
	* The program's software development has been plagued by problems, including delays, faulty software, and a lack of a common problem reporting system.
	* The program's maintainability requirements, including direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour, mean time to repair, and fault isolation, are not being met.
	* The program's weight growth has increased, affecting the aircraft's vertical rate of climb performance.

* The program's restructuring has extended the development phase by 3 years and delayed the start of operational testing until 2005.
	* The program's concurrency risks are still present, with the Army planning to start operational testing after the low-rate initial production decision is made.
	* The program's maintainability and software development issues remain unresolved, increasing the risk of higher program costs and delays.
	* The program's weight growth continues to affect the aircraft's performance, requiring further redesign of the engine.

</summary>

<summary>

• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide.
	• The program is funded by FNS, which also establishes regulations for implementing the program.
	• FNS requires states to certify household eligibility at least annually and establish requirements for households to report changes that occur after certification.

• The program has several options and waivers to increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families.
	• Options and waivers include program eligibility, reporting requirements, and extending food stamp benefits to households leaving TANF.
	• States can use these options to exclude certain assets, such as vehicles, from the determination of eligibility for food stamps.

• States have different approaches to implementing the program, including using categorical eligibility and reporting options.
	• Categorical eligibility allows households receiving certain TANF-funded services or benefits to be automatically eligible for food stamps.
	• Reporting options include monthly, quarterly, and semiannual reporting, as well as waivers to reduce the reporting burden on households with earnings.

• The program has faced challenges, including payment errors and declining participation.
	• Payment errors can occur due to incorrect determinations of household income or assets.
	• Declining participation may be due to changes in the program, such as the introduction of electronic benefits, or other factors.

• The program is subject to oversight and evaluation by FNS and the General Accounting Office.
	• FNS monitors states' performance by assessing their accuracy in determining food stamp eligibility and calculating benefits.
	• The General Accounting Office has reported on various aspects of the program, including its implementation, integrity, and participation challenges.

<summary>

* HUD is the principal federal agency responsible for programs in four areas: housing assistance, community development, housing finance, and regulatory issues.
	* HUD provides housing assistance through public housing authorities and private-market housing assistance under Section 8 of the U.S. Housing Act of 1937.
* Community Development: HUD provides community planning and development funds for local economic development, housing development, and assistance to the homeless.
	* HUD also supports fair housing programs and enforces federal fair housing laws.
* Housing Finance: The Federal Housing Administration (FHA) insures lenders against losses on mortgages for single-family properties, multifamily properties, and other facilities.
	* The Government National Mortgage Association guarantees investors the timely payment of principal and interest on securities issued by lenders of FHA-insured and VA- and Rural Housing Service-guaranteed loans.
* Regulatory Issues: HUD regulates interstate land sales, home mortgage settlement services, manufactured housing, lead-based paint abatement, and home mortgage disclosures.
	* HUD also supports fair housing programs and enforces federal fair housing laws.
* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs, with a total budget of about $28 billion in new discretionary budget authority.
	* The budget request includes set-asides for 10 projects or initiatives totaling about $428 million, including new initiatives totaling about $60 million.
* HUD is proposing an increase in its EZ Program, with a $150 million request for Urban Empowerment Zones, including $45 million for Strategic Planning Communities.
	* HUD is also proposing an increase in its Section 8 housing assistance program, with a request for $3.1 billion in new funding.
* HUD's capacity to manage its programs is a concern, given its current organizational reform and the need to plan and implement new initiatives.
	* HUD's Inspector General and the National Academy of Public Administration have cited weaknesses in HUD's contracting and procurement practices.

</summary>

<summary>
• The Military Health System operated by DOD is large and complex, with a dual health care mission of readiness and benefits.
	• The readiness mission provides medical services and support to the armed forces during contingency operations, while the benefits mission provides medical services and support to members of the armed forces, their families, and others eligible for DOD health care.
• The replacement medical center is being designed to serve as the only tertiary-level referral hospital in Europe, serving beneficiaries from the EUCOM, Central Command, Africa Command, and Special Operations Command areas of responsibility.
	• The facility is being designed to accommodate contingency operations, with the ability to expand capacity during surges to handle casualties.
• The facility requirements were developed using a combination of patient workload data, historical patterns of patient migration, and contingency operations, but the documentation of the process was incomplete and contained errors.
	• The cost estimate for the facility was developed using a combination of historical records and actual experiences from other comparable programs, but the documentation of the process was incomplete and did not fully meet best practices for cost estimating.
</summary>

<summary>
* ICE's guidance on exercising discretion during alien apprehension and removal process is not comprehensive and has not been updated to reflect expanded worksite and fugitive operations.
	* ICE's field operational manuals and memorandums do not provide clear guidance on exercising discretion for aliens with humanitarian issues or aliens who are not primary targets of ICE investigations.
	* ICE's guidance on detention and removal decisions is not consistently disseminated to all field offices, and officers may not receive necessary legal guidance in a timely manner.
* ICE's internal control standards are not fully implemented, and the agency lacks a mechanism to analyze information on officer decision making regarding alien apprehensions and removals.
	* ICE's supervisory review and inspection program do not provide managers with information to analyze officer decision making for trends across all field offices, making it difficult to identify areas that may require corrective action.
	* ICE's inspection program is not designed to analyze information on officer decision making regarding alien apprehensions and removals, and the agency lacks a mechanism to collect and analyze data on the exercise of discretion.
* ICE's training programs are being updated, but it is too soon to assess their effectiveness in providing officers with the necessary guidance and tools to exercise discretion.
	* ICE's training programs are not designed to provide officers with comprehensive guidance on exercising discretion in all phases of the alien apprehension and removal process.
	* ICE's training programs do not provide officers with information on how to weigh humanitarian factors and other relevant circumstances when making decisions about alien apprehension and removal.
</summary>

<summary>
* Ground ambulance services are provided by a wide range of organizations with varying structures, staffing, and revenue sources.
	* Providers may be affiliated with institutions, independent, or government-based.
	* They may rely on volunteers, paid staff, or a combination of both.
	* Revenue sources include community tax support, charitable donations, grants, and payments from Medicare and private insurance companies.
* Medicare payments for ambulance services are made up of two components: a service-level payment and a mileage payment.
	* The service-level payment is based on the type of transport provided, such as ALS or BLS.
	* The mileage payment is determined by the number of miles traveled and the mileage base rate.
* Providers' costs for ground ambulance transports vary greatly, ranging from $224 to $2,204 per transport.
	* The median cost per transport was $429 in 2010.
	* Providers' Medicare margins, or the difference between Medicare payments and costs, also vary greatly.
	* The median Medicare margin was 2% in 2010, but some providers had negative margins.
</summary>

<summary>
• Military services have not consistently ensured timely, complete, and accurate information to maintain full visibility of SRC I ammunition in the continental United States.
	• The Army has not ensured timely and complete information of SRC I ammunition returned to the contractor, but has begun to take action to improve visibility.
	• The military services have not always entered timely information in the Defense Transportation Tracking System (DTTS) on shipments to aid Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command tracking by satellite.
	• The military services have entered incomplete or inaccurate data in DTTS about shipments of SRC I ammunition.
	• The Army has not maintained accountability for all in-transit items within the logistics records for that materiel until there is a formal acknowledgement of receipt.

<summary>
• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and is designed to protect individuals' privacy and uphold the pledge of confidentiality.
  • The policy requires SSA to consider several factors before disclosing information to law enforcement, including the nature of the alleged criminal activity, the information requested, and the agency making the request.
  • SSA's policy does not permit disclosure of tax return information, and the agency has a long-standing pledge to maintain the confidentiality of its records.
• SSA's disclosure policy is not consistently applied across all field offices, and some staff may be confused about what information can be disclosed.
  • The agency's policy is not readily available to law enforcement, and some officers may not be familiar with the process for obtaining information from SSA.
  • Law enforcement officials generally are satisfied with the information provided by SSA, but some believe that the agency's policy is too restrictive and that more information should be disclosed for legitimate investigations.
</summary>

<summary>

• RCRA's requirements pose significant barriers to cleanups
  • Land disposal restrictions and minimum technological requirements are unduly stringent for remediation waste
  • Permit requirements add complexity and cost to the cleanup process

• EPA has implemented policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of RCRA's requirements
  • Contained-in policy allows for exclusion of contaminated media from RCRA's regulation
  • CAMU rule allows for consolidation of remediation waste and treatment or capping without triggering treatment standards

• Stakeholders disagree on the extent to which waste should be exempt from RCRA's requirements
  • Some stakeholders prefer a bright-line approach, while others prefer a unitary approach
  • EPA's proposed rule was withdrawn due to disagreements and legal challenges

• EPA believes that comprehensive reform of RCRA's requirements is necessary
  • The agency has concluded that reform can best be achieved through legislative action
  • EPA has withdrawn its proposed rule and is pursuing narrower regulatory changes

• The agency has identified three specific requirements that pose the most significant barriers to cleanups
  • Land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements
  • Reforming these individual requirements would not remove all barriers; RCRA's entire hazardous waste management process poses problems

• EPA believes that reform must apply to all remediation waste, including sludge, debris, and contaminated soil
  • The agency has provided policy and regulatory alternatives to help parties manage cleanups under RCRA's current requirements
  • However, the agency acknowledges that the benefits may be limited until comprehensive reform is achieved

• The report recommends that EPA take steps to ensure that regulators have a consistent understanding of how to apply policy and regulatory alternatives
  • The agency should consolidate policy and regulatory alternatives into one guidance document and provide training and legal assistance for site-specific implementation questions
  • The report also recommends that the agency take steps to address the disincentives to cleanups posed by RCRA's requirements until comprehensive reform is achieved

</summary>

<summary>

* Medicare's program integrity funding is used to support various activities, including audits, medical reviews, and provider education.
	* * The funding is allocated to contractors who conduct these activities, such as intermediaries, carriers, and Medicare administrative contractors (MACs).
	* * The funding is used to support the contractors' efforts to identify and prevent fraud, waste, and abuse in the Medicare program.
	* * The funding is also used to support the development of new technologies and methods to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the program integrity activities.

* The allocation of program integrity funding is based on a variety of factors, including the contractor's past performance, the type of activity being conducted, and the level of risk associated with the activity.
	* * The funding is allocated to contractors who have a history of effective program integrity activities and who are able to demonstrate a high level of performance.
	* * The funding is also allocated to contractors who are conducting high-risk activities, such as medical reviews and provider education, which require a high level of expertise and resources.
	* * The funding is not allocated solely based on the contractor's costs, but rather on the level of risk associated with the activity and the potential for savings or benefits to the program.

* The program integrity funding is used to support a variety of activities, including audits, medical reviews, and provider education.
	* * Audits are used to identify and prevent fraud, waste, and abuse in the Medicare program.
	* * Medical reviews are used to ensure that Medicare claims are accurate and complete, and to identify and prevent overpayments.
	* * Provider education is used to educate healthcare providers about the Medicare program and to help them understand their responsibilities and obligations under the program.

* The program integrity funding is also used to support the development of new technologies and methods to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the program integrity activities.
	* * The funding is used to support the development of new data analytics tools and methods to identify and prevent fraud, waste, and abuse.

* The program integrity funding is critical to the success of the Medicare program, as it helps to ensure that the program is administered fairly and efficiently.

<summary>

* IRS faces challenges in managing its human capital to provide telephone customer service to taxpayers.
	* * The challenges include recruiting, training, and retaining customer service representatives.
	* * The challenges also include evaluating the effectiveness of human capital management practices.
	* * The challenges are exacerbated by the need to set a long-term, desired service-level goal based on taxpayer needs.

* IRS has made or planned substantial improvements to help meet these challenges.
	* * The improvements include establishing a system for assessing customer service representatives' competency gaps and meeting the refresher training needs identified by the assessments.
	* * The improvements also include developing a system for monitoring call center attrition and identifying its causes.
	* * The improvements will help ensure that customer service representatives have the competencies and training needed to respond to taxpayer calls.

* The Commissioner of Internal Revenue agrees with the recommendations and has provided written comments on a draft of this report.
	* * The Commissioner has instituted an agencywide strategic planning process that links the budget and available resources to its strategies and improvement projects.
	* * The Commissioner has also recognized the need to strengthen the new process and has planned to do so.
	* * The Commissioner has not commented on monitoring why employees leave or on using this information to strengthen IRS' efforts to retain skilled representatives.

* The Commissioner has also recognized the importance of retaining skilled representatives.
	* * The Commissioner has identified several efforts that focus on identifying employees that may be more likely to remain with IRS.
	* * The Commissioner has not commented on using this information to strengthen IRS' efforts to retain skilled representatives.
	* * The Commissioner has not commented on the effects of IRS' human capital practices on its ability to achieve its long- and short-term customer service goals.

* The Commissioner has used the Human Capital Self-Assessment Checklist for Agency Leaders as a diagnostic tool.
	* * The Commissioner has used the checklist to review its mid- and top-level management realignment process.
	* * The Commissioner plans to use the checklist again in fiscal year 2001 to conduct an overview of the status of human capital practices throughout the Service.
	* * The checklist provides a framework by which agency leaders can develop informed views of their agencies' human capital policies and practices.

</summary>

<summary>
• Ginnie Mae is a government-sponsored enterprise that securitizes government-backed mortgages.
	• It was created in 1968 to expand affordable housing opportunities.
	• It operates as a unit of the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD).
• Ginnie Mae's mission is to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the nation's housing markets.
	• It does this by providing guarantees to investors in mortgage-backed securities (MBS).
	• The guarantees ensure timely payment of principal and interest to investors.
• Ginnie Mae's MBS are backed by government-insured or guaranteed mortgages.
	• The agency's securities are traded in the secondary market.
	• Ginnie Mae's market share of government-backed mortgage market has declined over the past 20 years.
	• The agency faces challenges in responding to changes in the marketplace and meeting the needs of its stakeholders.
</summary>

<summary>
• DOD's illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments
  • The report found that DOD made $615 million of illegal and otherwise improper adjustments to closed appropriation accounts in fiscal year 2000
  • The adjustments were made due to a lack of basic controls and managerial attention required to properly account for disbursements
  • The report recommended that DOD take actions to correct the problems and prevent similar issues in the future
  • DOD agreed with the recommendations and outlined its ongoing and planned actions to identify, reverse, and correct the illegal and otherwise improper adjustments

• DOD's efforts to correct the problems
  • DOD has taken steps to implement controls to identify and prevent illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments
  • The report found that DOD's efforts have resulted in an 80% reduction in closed account adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002
  • DOD plans to complete its reaudits and corrective actions by September 30, 2004
  • The report recommended that DOD continue to monitor its efforts to ensure that any potential Antideficiency Act violations are promptly investigated and reported

• The report's recommendations
  • The report recommended that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to direct the Director of the Defense Finance and Accounting Service to help ensure that DFAS Columbus completes its review and correction of the remaining fiscal year 2000 illegal and otherwise improper adjustments
  • The report also recommended that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to continue to monitor the adjustments to ensure that any potential Antideficiency Act violations are promptly investigated and reported
  • The report recommended that DOD continue to work to simplify accounting and contract payment allocation terms and modernize its financial management systems
  • The report recommended that DOD provide a sustained commitment to addressing its financial management and contract payment problems over the long term
</summary>

<summary>
• The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) was established to manage the domain name system (DNS) and ensure the stability and security of the Internet.
  • ICANN was created in 1998 as a private, non-profit corporation to take over the management of the DNS from the U.S. government.
  • The Department of Commerce and ICANN entered into a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) in 1998 to design, develop, and test the methods and procedures necessary to transfer DNS management to ICANN.
  • ICANN's initial Board of Directors was composed of 19 members, including 9 members elected "at-large" and 10 appointed by the Department of Commerce.
  • ICANN's mission was to ensure the stability and security of the DNS, promote competition and representation, and provide a private, bottom-up coordination mechanism for the Internet community.
  • ICANN's progress was slow, and the transition was behind schedule, leading to concerns about the future of the DNS and the role of ICANN.
  • In 2002, ICANN's president proposed reforms to address the slow progress and concerns about the organization's effectiveness, including changes to the Board's composition and the introduction of a new top-level domain name system.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) is responsible for managing the trust funds of individual Indians and Indian tribes.
	* OST was established in 1994 to address the historical trust responsibility of the federal government to manage Indian trust funds.
	* The trust funds are held in trust by the federal government for the benefit of individual Indians and Indian tribes.
* OST has implemented several trust reforms to improve the management of the trust funds.
	* The reforms include the development of a comprehensive trust management plan, the implementation of a new accounting system, and the establishment of a risk management program.
* The trust reforms are designed to improve the accuracy and transparency of the trust fund accounting and to reduce the risk of mismanagement or loss of trust funds.
	* The reforms also aim to improve the communication and coordination between OST and the Indian tribes and to provide better services to the beneficiaries of the trust funds.
* The Special Trustee has not provided a timetable for completing the trust reforms, which has hindered the ability of the Congress to oversee the implementation of the reforms.
	* The Special Trustee has also not developed a plan for future trust fund operations once the reforms are completed.
* The report recommends that the Secretary of the Interior direct the Special Trustee to provide a timetable for completing the trust reforms and to develop a plan for future trust fund operations.

<summary>
• VA and DOD have made progress in sharing patient health information, but still face challenges in achieving their long-term goals.
  • The departments have implemented near-term demonstration projects, such as Bidirectional Health Information Exchange (BHIE) and Laboratory Data Sharing Interface (LDSI), which have improved the exchange of health information.
    • BHIE enables the two-way exchange of information on shared patients, while LDSI allows for the sharing of laboratory resources.
  • The departments have also made progress in developing a project management plan for the CHDR program, but still need to finalize the plan and address several challenges.
    • The plan lacks detail on specific tasks and time frames, and security policy has not yet been finalized.
    • The departments need to overcome these challenges to achieve their long-term goals of creating a virtual medical record based on the two-way exchange of computable data between their health information systems.
</summary>

<summary>

• IRS' desired outcome of an income tax audit is to determine the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit.
	• The auditor has a responsibility to conduct a quality audit to ensure the correct outcome.
	• The IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, which address scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management of an audit.
• The audit workpapers provide documentation on the scope of the audit and the diligence with which it was completed.
	• Workpapers assist in planning the audit, record procedures applied, tests performed, and evidence gathered, and provide support for technical conclusions.
	• Workpapers also provide the basis for review by management and are the principal support for the auditor's report.
• The IRS uses the Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) to collect information about the audit process, changes to the process, level of audit quality, and success of efforts to improve the process and quality.
	• EQMS staff review audit workpapers and assess the degree to which the auditor complied with the audit standards.
• The IRS requires group managers to review audit workpapers to ensure quality and ensure that audit standards are being met.
	• However, the review is not always documented in the workpapers, and the extent of supervisory review cannot be determined.
• The IRS is drafting changes to the Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) to require documentation of managerial involvement in the audit process.
	• The GAO recommends that the IRS Commissioner require audit supervisors to document their review of audit workpapers as a control over the quality of audits and workpapers.

</summary>

	* * The assessments and reviews do not consistently provide a basis for targeting program assistance to the areas of greatest need.

* The program lacks clear measures of sustainability, and the concept of sustainability is not integrated into country-specific planning.

<summary>

* Large financial companies can be reorganized or liquidated through a judicial bankruptcy process or a regulatory resolution process.
	* The judicial bankruptcy process is governed by the Bankruptcy Code and involves a court-supervised reorganization or liquidation of the company's assets.
	* The regulatory resolution process is governed by the Dodd-Frank Act and involves the Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) working together to resolve the company's financial difficulties.
* The Bankruptcy Code provides for two main types of bankruptcy proceedings: Chapter 7 and Chapter 11.
	* Chapter 7 is a liquidation proceeding in which the company's assets are sold and the proceeds are distributed to creditors.
	* Chapter 11 is a reorganization proceeding in which the company is restructured and a plan is developed to pay off its debts.
* The Bankruptcy Code also provides for special procedures for resolving large financial companies, such as the Financial Institution Bankruptcy Act of 2014.
	* This act provides for a new chapter in the Bankruptcy Code, Chapter 14, which allows for the reorganization of large financial companies in a way that is similar to Chapter 11, but with some additional procedures and requirements.
* The regulatory resolution process is governed by the Dodd-Frank Act and involves the Federal Reserve and the FDIC working together to resolve the company's financial difficulties.
	* The Dodd-Frank Act provides for a number of procedures and requirements for resolving large financial companies, including the requirement that the company develop a resolution plan and the requirement that the Federal Reserve and the FDIC work together to resolve the company's financial difficulties.
* The Bankruptcy Code and the Dodd-Frank Act provide for a number of procedures and requirements for resolving large financial companies, including the requirement that the company develop a resolution plan and the requirement that the Federal Reserve and the FDIC work together to resolve the company's financial difficulties.
	* The Bankruptcy Code and the Dodd-Frank Act also provide for a number of procedures and requirements for resolving large financial companies, including the requirement that the company develop a resolution plan and the requirement that the Federal Reserve and the FDIC work together to resolve the company's financial difficulties.

* The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
	* * Generation involves producing electricity through various sources, such as fossil fuels, nuclear power, and renewable energy.
	* * Transmission and distribution involve moving electricity from the generation source to the consumer.
* The electricity grid is vulnerable to cyber-based threats, including intentional and unintentional attacks.
	* * Intentional attacks can be carried out by hackers, foreign nations, and other malicious actors.
	* * Unintentional attacks can occur due to human error, software bugs, or natural disasters.
* The government and industry have taken steps to secure the grid, including developing cybersecurity standards and guidelines.
	* * NERC has developed critical infrastructure protection standards for protecting electric utility-critical and cyber-critical assets.
	* * FERC has reviewed and approved these standards and has taken steps to improve cybersecurity protections.
* The GAO has identified several challenges in securing the grid, including the need for better monitoring of cybersecurity standards and the need for clearer regulatory responsibilities.
	* * The GAO recommends that FERC work with NERC to assess the effectiveness of cybersecurity standards and develop strategies for addressing gaps in compliance.
	* * The GAO also recommends that FERC clarify regulatory responsibilities and take a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity.

</summary>
